summary: all public health and most hospital services are under the direction of the Health Bureau of Guangdong Provincial People’s Government. the public health function is performed by one provincial center for Disease Control and several municipal centers. 3) leukocyte count 10.0 x 109/L, 4) radiographic evidence of infiltrates consistent with pneumonia or respiratory distress syndrome on chest x-ray, and 5) no response to antimicrobial drug treatment. patients were considered probable SARS patients if they meet criteria 1–4 or 2–5 but excluded if an alternative diagnosis could fully explain their illness. incidence rates were calculated for November 2002 to April 2003. younger adults were used as the reference group for both children and older persons. chi-square test or, when appropriate, Fisher exact test was used for comparison of proportions. cases of atypical pneumonia (probable SARS) were only included in the database if they conformed to the case definition subsequently adopted for surveillance. patients were considered probable SARS patients if they meet criteria 1–4 or 2–5 but excluded if an alternative diagnosis could fully explain their illness. data were entered into Excel databases (Microsoft, Redmond, WA) descriptive analyses were carried out using EpiInfo version 6 (Centers for Disease Control, Atlanta, GA) and SPSS version 10.0 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL) the case investigation database was used for analysis by age, sex, occupation, and clinical signs and symptoms. the highest incidence occurred in Guangzhou city (12.5 cases per 100,000 people) outbreaks appear to have occurred in different municipalities at varying stages of the epidemic. median age of patients was 35.0 years (range 0–92 years) number of patients with severe acute respiratory syndrome by age, and age-specific incidence (per 10,000 population), November 1, 2002–April 30, 2003, Guangdong Province, China. a high proportion (9/23, 39%) of early cases in food handlers were food handlers. six of the food handlers lived or worked in Shunde (1.7 million population), an urban district of Foshan municipality. none could be directly linked to each other through contact history. aSARS, severe acute respiratory syndrome, is a severe acute respiratory syndrome. children were more likely to have a runny nose and dry cough on physical examination but less likely to have chills, malaise, headache, muscle aches, or difficulty breathing. all patients had a high body temperature (median 39.0°C, range 36.8–42.0°C) lasting in most patients for 1 to 4 days. headache live within walking distance of a produce market (an agricultural market where live animals are sold, killed, and butchered in situ) living near poultry or livestock farm or having other types of animal contact, including domestic pets or livestock, poultry, or specific wild animals or birds, was not associated with a high risk for SARS. aSARS, severe acute respiratory syndrome; CI, confidence interval; OR, odds ratio. index patients in each of the seven earliest affected municipalities had a date of onset before January 31, 2003. in five municipalities (Foshan, Jiangmen, Zhongshan, Guangzhou, Shenzhen), outbreaks appear to have occurred independently, but the outbreak in Heyuan may be linked to that in Shenzhen and the outbreak in Zhaoqing to that in Guangzhou. patient 2 lived in Heyuan but worked as a restaurant chef in shenzhen. his work was stir-frying and did not involve killing animals. he returned to Heyuan after becoming ill and was transferred to Guangzhou 2 days later. patient 6, from shenzhen, had visited Hong Kong on January 14, the day before symptom onset. he infected a work colleague (43-year-old man, onset January 29) and died 14 days after becoming ill. she worked at a market but did not sell animals. the highest incidence occurred in Guangzhou city (12.5 cases per 100,000 people) outbreaks appear to have occurred in different municipalities at different stages of the epidemic. median age of patients was 35.0 years (range 0–92 years) and highest age-specific incidence was in persons 65–69 years (3.2 per 100,000 people) number of patients cases in food handlers, seven were restaurant chefs working in township restaurants. six of the food handlers lived or worked in Shunde (1.7 million population), an urban district of Foshan contact, including domestic pets or livestock, poultry, or specific wild animals or birds, was not associated with a high risk for SARS. aSARS, severe acute respiratory syndrome; CI, confidence interval; OR, odds ratio. index patients in each of the seven earliest affected municipalities had a date of onset before January 31, 2003 (Table 6). in five municipalities (Foshan, Jiangmen, Zhongshan, Guangzhou, Shenzhen), outbreaks appear to have occurred independently, but the outbreak in Heyuan may be linked to that in Shenzhen and the outbreak in Zhaoqing to that in Guangzhou. patient 2 lived in Heyuan but worked as a restaurant chef in shenzhen. his work was stir-frying and did not involve killing animals. he returned to Heyuan after becoming ill and was transferred to Guangzhou 2 days later. patient 6, from shenzhen, visited Hong Kong on January 14, the day before symptom onset. he infected a work colleague (43-year-old man, onset January 29) and died 14 days after becoming ill. she worked at a market but did not sell animals. evidence of infection has been found in a raccoon dog (Nyctereutes procyonoides), a Chinese ferret-badger (Melogale moschata) and humans working at a live animal market in shenzen municipality (14). the pattern of the Guangdong epidemic is consistent with the classical process of emergence from an animal reservoir. the index patient in Guangxi Province was a wild animal trader. the index patient was a wild animal trader who supplied Guangdong markets. surveillance for SARS was only established in February 2003. sensitivity and specificity are unknown. initial source of the epidemic was either a single point source or several point sources in the pearl river basin. outbreaks in cities affected later in the epidemic can all be traced to an imported case. these later cases are probably due to horizontal transmission rather than to further contact with the initial source. is the continuing existence of an environmental source; however, this explanation is not borne out by case investigation data. this factor is important not only to understand the transmission dynamics of SARS but also to allay concerns about the risk for epidemic spread in the community if SARS is reintroduced.
